durations.title: Flood to Abraham: 352 Years
durations.description: Calculated from Genesis 11 post-flood genealogy: Flood→Arphaxad (2) + Arphaxad→Salah (35) + Salah→Eber (30) + Eber→Peleg (34) + Peleg→Reu (30) + Reu→Serug (32) + Serug→Nahor (30) + Nahor→Terah (29) + Terah→Abraham (130) = 352 years. Note: Terah was 130 (not 70) when Abraham was born, derived from Acts 7:4 (Abraham left after Terah died) + Gen 11:32 (Terah died at 205) + Gen 12:4 (Abraham was 75 when he left): 205 - 75 = 130.

sources.quote: Shem was an hundred years old, and begat Arphaxad **two years after the flood**.
And Arphaxad lived **five and thirty years**, and begat Salah.
And Salah lived **thirty years**, and begat Eber.
And Eber lived **four and thirty years**, and begat Peleg.
And Peleg lived **thirty years**, and begat Reu.
And Reu lived **two and thirty years**, and begat Serug.
And Serug lived **thirty years**, and begat Nahor.
And Nahor lived **nine and twenty years**, and begat Terah.
And the days of Terah were **two hundred and five years**: and Terah died in Haran.
So Abram departed... and **Abram was seventy and five years old** when he departed out of Haran.
Then came he out of the land of the Chaldaeans, and dwelt in Charran: and from thence, **when his father was dead, he removed him into this land**.

durations.notes: The 352-year calculation: 2 + 35 + 30 + 34 + 30 + 32 + 30 + 29 + 130 = 352. Genesis 11:26 says Terah was 70 when he begat 'Abram, Nahor, and Haran' but this likely refers to the firstborn. Abraham was actually born when Terah was 130, proven by: Terah died at 205 (Gen 11:32), Abraham left after Terah died (Acts 7:4), Abraham was 75 when he left (Gen 12:4), therefore 205 - 75 = 130.

claimed.notes: Inclusive counting derivation: Year 3 (36 BC, Jerusalem) → Year 2 (37 BC) → Year 1 (38 BC). This is the anchor calculation that determines Herod's chronology.

sources.quote: Herod took Jerusalem in his 3rd regal year
36 BC (Year 3, Jerusalem capture) - 2 years (inclusive) = 38 BC (Year 1 begins Nisan 1)

durations.title: David Lived 70 Years

source.quote: David was **thirty years old** when he began to reign, and he reigned **forty years**
And the time that he reigned over Israel was **forty years**; seven years reigned he in Hebron, and thirty and three years reigned he in Jerusalem
Now king David was old... And king David said, Call me Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet... and cause Solomon my son to ride upon mine own mule... and anoint him there king over Israel
So when David was old and full of days, **he made Solomon his son king over Israel**

durations.notes: David was 30 years old when he began to reign (2 Sam 5:4) and reigned 40 years (1 Kings 2:11), making him 70 at death. Scripture confirms Solomon was anointed king while David was still alive (1 Kings 1), making Solomon's first year overlap with David's final year. Jewish tradition (Talmud Shabbat 30a) holds David died on Shavuot, his 70th birthday.

durations.title: Solomon Appointed King While David Alive

claimed.notes: Same year - co-regency

source.quote: And king David said, Call me Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah... cause **Solomon my son** to ride upon mine own mule, and bring him down to Gihon: And let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet **anoint him there king over Israel**
So when David was old and full of days, **he made Solomon his son king over Israel**

And they made Solomon the son of David king the second time, and anointed him unto the LORD to be the chief governor... Then **Solomon sat on the throne of the LORD as king instead of David his father**

durations.notes: Scripture explicitly states David appointed Solomon as king while still alive. Solomon was anointed 'the second time' (1 Chr 29:22), indicating a brief co-regency. David died in Solomon's first year (on Shavuot), making their reigns overlap by several months.

durations.title: 1000 Years: David's Death to Christ's Death

claimed.notes: 1000 years inclusive from David's death on Shavuot to the Crucifixion of Yeshua

source.quote: Men and brethren, let me freely speak unto you of the patriarch David, that he is both dead and buried, and his sepulchre is with us unto this day. Therefore being a prophet, and knowing that God had sworn with an oath to him, that of the fruit of his loins, according to the flesh, he would raise up Christ to sit on his throne; He seeing this before spake of the resurrection of Christ.

durations.notes: David dies 969 BC, Yeshua crucified 32 AD = exactly 1000 years (inclusive counting). Peter explicitly connects David's death with Christ's resurrection on the day of Shavuot.

durations.notes: Exactly 70 years of temple desolation, fulfilling Jeremiah's prophecy.

durations.title: Jeremiah's 70 Years: Babylon's Dominion

source.quote: And these nations shall serve the king of Babylon seventy years. And it shall come to pass, when seventy years are accomplished, that I will punish the king of Babylon

durations.notes: From first captivity (605 BC) to fall of Babylon (539 BC) = 66 years. Alternatively from 609 BC (Nebuchadnezzar's father Nabopolassar defeats Assyria) to 539 BC = 70 years. The prophecy may count from Babylon's rise to dominance.

durations.title: Jeremiah's 70 Years: Temple Desolation to Completion

source.quote: O LORD of hosts, how long wilt thou not have mercy on Jerusalem and on the cities of Judah, against which thou hast had indignation these threescore and ten years?

durations.notes: 587 BC (temple destruction) to 517 BC (temple completed) = exactly 70 years. Zechariah asks in Darius's 2nd year (520 BC), 67 years in. Temple completed 3 years later = 70 years exactly.

durations.title: Proof of Regnal Year Counting: Neb 7th vs 8th

source.quote: Jeremiah: 'in the seventh year' vs Kings: 'in the eighth year of his reign'

durations.notes: The same captivity event is dated to Nebuchadnezzar's 7th year (Jeremiah, regnal) and 8th year (Kings, accession-year). This 1-year difference proves Jeremiah uses regnal (non-accession) counting, which applies to all prophetic books including Haggai, Zechariah, and Ezra.

source.quote: Accordingly, the number of the high priests, from the days of Herod until the day when Titus took the temple and the city, and burnt them, were in all 28; the time also that belonged to them was **107 years**.

durations.notes: From Herod's 'days' (his first regnal year after Roman appointment, 38 BC) to the fall of the Temple (70 AD) = ~107 years. This duration confirms Herod's reign beginning in 38 BC and provides a sixth independent line of evidence for the 1 BC death date.

events.title: Methuselah Dies
events.description: Methuselah dies at age 969, the oldest recorded human. His death coincides with the beginning of the flood - the same year Noah entered the ark.

sources.quote: And all the days of Methuselah were **nine hundred sixty and nine years**: and he died.

events.title: Adam Dies
events.description: Adam dies at age 930, the first human to experience death (besides Abel who was murdered).

sources.quote: And all the days that Adam lived were **nine hundred and thirty years**: and he died.

events.title: Seth Dies
events.description: Seth dies at age 912.

sources.quote: And all the days of Seth were **nine hundred and twelve years**: and he died.

events.title: Enos Dies
events.description: Enos dies at age 905.

sources.quote: And all the days of Enos were **nine hundred and five years**: and he died.

events.title: Cainan Dies
events.description: Cainan dies at age 910.

sources.quote: And all the days of Cainan were **nine hundred and ten years**: and he died.

events.title: Mahalaleel Dies
events.description: Mahalaleel dies at age 895.

sources.quote: And all the days of Mahalaleel were **eight hundred ninety and five years**: and he died.

events.title: Jared Dies
events.description: Jared dies at age 962.

sources.quote: And all the days of Jared were **nine hundred sixty and two years**: and he died.

events.title: Enoch Translated (Taken by God)
events.description: Enoch, after walking with God for 365 years, is taken by God without seeing death - the first recorded 'rapture' or translation.

sources.quote: And all the days of Enoch were **three hundred sixty and five years**: And Enoch walked with God: and **he was not; for God took him**.
By faith Enoch was **translated that he should not see death**; and was not found, because **God had translated him**.

events.title: Lamech Dies
events.description: Lamech (Noah's father) dies at age 777, five years before the flood.

sources.quote: And all the days of Lamech were **seven hundred seventy and seven years**: and he died.

events.title: Noah Dies
events.description: Noah dies at age 950, 350 years after the flood.

sources.quote: And all the days of Noah were **nine hundred and fifty years**: and he died.

events.title: Methuselah Born
events.description: Methuselah is born to Enoch. He will live 969 years - the longest recorded lifespan - dying the year of the flood.

sources.quote: And Methuselah lived an hundred eighty and seven years, and begat Lamech... And all the days of Methuselah were nine hundred sixty and nine years: and he died.

events.title: Lamech Born (Noah's Father)
events.description: Lamech is born to Methuselah when Methuselah was 187 years old. Lamech was 182 when Noah was born.

sources.quote: And Methuselah lived **an hundred eighty and seven years**, and begat Lamech.
And Lamech lived **an hundred eighty and two years**, and begat a son: And he called his name Noah.

events.title: Noah Born
events.description: Noah is born to Lamech when Lamech was 182 years old. Noah was 600 years old when the flood came.

start.notes: Noah was 600 years old in the year of the flood (Genesis 7:6)

sources.quote: And Lamech lived **an hundred eighty and two years**, and begat a son: And he called his name Noah.
And Noah was **six hundred years old** when the flood of waters was upon the earth.

events.title: Enoch Born
events.description: Enoch is born to Jared when Jared was 162 years old. Enoch will walk with God and be taken without seeing death.

sources.quote: And Jared lived **an hundred sixty and two years**, and he begat Enoch... And Enoch lived **sixty and five years**, and begat Methuselah.

events.title: Jared Born
events.description: Jared is born to Mahalaleel when Mahalaleel was 65 years old.

sources.quote: And Mahalaleel lived **sixty and five years**, and begat Jared... And Jared lived **an hundred sixty and two years**, and he begat Enoch.

events.title: Mahalaleel Born
events.description: Mahalaleel is born to Cainan when Cainan was 70 years old.

sources.quote: And Cainan lived **seventy years**, and begat Mahalaleel... And Mahalaleel lived **sixty and five years**, and begat Jared.

events.title: Cainan Born
events.description: Cainan is born to Enos when Enos was 90 years old.

sources.quote: And Enos lived **ninety years**, and begat Cainan... And Cainan lived **seventy years**, and begat Mahalaleel.

events.title: Enos Born
events.description: Enos is born to Seth when Seth was 105 years old.

sources.quote: And Seth lived **an hundred and five years**, and begat Enos... And Enos lived **ninety years**, and begat Cainan.

events.title: Seth Born
events.description: Seth is born to Adam when Adam was 130 years old, after the death of Abel.

sources.quote: And Adam lived **an hundred and thirty years**, and begat a son in his own likeness, after his image; and called his name Seth... And Seth lived **an hundred and five years**, and begat Enos.

events.title: Adam Created
events.description: Adam is created by God on the 6th day of creation. This marks the beginning of human history and Anno Mundi (Year of the World).

sources.quote: And God said, **Let us make man in our image**, after our likeness... So **God created man** in his own image.
In the day that **God created man**... And Adam lived **an hundred and thirty years**, and begat a son.

events.title: Noah's Flood Begins
events.description: In Noah's 600th year, on the 17th day of the 2nd month, the fountains of the deep burst forth and the windows of heaven opened. Rain falls for 40 days and nights.

start.notes: 352 years before Abraham (Gen 11:10-26 genealogy)

sources.quote: In the **six hundredth year of Noah's life**, in the **second month, the seventeenth day of the month**, the same day were all the fountains of the great deep broken up, and the windows of heaven were opened.

events.title: Noah Enters the Ark
events.description: Noah enters the ark with his family and all the animals, 7 days before the flood begins. Noah was 600 years old when the flood waters came. God shut the door after 7 days of waiting.

sources.quote: And **Noah went in**, and his sons, and his wife, and his sons' wives with him, **into the ark**, because of the waters of the flood... And it came to pass **after seven days**, that the waters of the flood were upon the earth.
**In the selfsame day** entered Noah, and Shem, and Ham, and Japheth, the sons of Noah, and Noah's wife, and the three wives of his sons with them, into the ark... And **the LORD shut him in**.

events.title: Rain Continues 40 Days
events.description: Rain continues for 40 days and nights. Waters increase and lift the ark. Mountains are covered by 15 cubits as the floodwaters rise.

sources.quote: And the rain was upon the earth **forty days and forty nights**.
And the flood was **forty days** upon the earth; and the waters increased, and **bare up the ark**, and it was lift up above the earth.
And the waters prevailed exceedingly upon the earth; and **all the high hills, that were under the whole heaven, were covered**.

events.title: Waters Prevail 150 Days
events.description: The waters prevailed upon the earth for 150 days total from the start of the flood. This period includes the 40 days of rain plus the continued prevailing of the waters.

sources.quote: And the waters prevailed upon the earth **an hundred and fifty days**.

events.title: Ark Rests on Mountains of Ararat
events.description: On the 17th day of the 7th month, after 150 days of prevailing waters (exactly 5 months later, assuming 30-day months), the ark comes to rest on the mountains of Ararat as floodwaters recede.

sources.quote: And the ark rested **in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month**, upon the mountains of Ararat.

events.title: Tops of Mountains Seen
events.description: On the 1st day of the 10th month, the tops of the mountains are seen. Waters continue to decrease.

sources.quote: And the waters decreased continually until the **tenth month**: in the **tenth month, on the first day of the month**, were the tops of the mountains seen.

events.title: Noah Sends Raven and Dove
events.description: At the end of forty days after the mountain tops were seen, Noah opens the window of the ark and sends forth a raven, which went forth to and fro. He also sends a dove, but it finds no rest and returns. The raven did not return.

sources.quote: And it came to pass **at the end of forty days**, that Noah opened the window of the ark which he had made: And **he sent forth a raven**, which went forth to and fro, until the waters were dried up from off the earth.

events.title: Dove Returns with Olive Leaf
events.description: Noah sends a dove three times: first it returns with nothing (no rest), second it returns with an olive leaf (waters abated), third it doesn't return (earth ready).

start.notes: Genesis 8:8 'Also he sent forth a dove' - same day as raven. After 7 days (v10), second dove returns with olive leaf.

sources.quote: Also **he sent forth a dove**... But the dove found no rest... And he stayed yet **other seven days**; and again he sent forth the dove... **in her mouth was an olive leaf**... And he stayed yet **other seven days**; and sent forth the dove; which **returned not again**.

events.title: Waters Dried Up - Noah Removes Ark Covering
events.description: In the 601st year, on the 1st day of the 1st month, the waters were dried up from off the earth. Noah removes the covering of the ark and sees that the face of the ground was dry.

relative.notes: Next Nisan 1 after the flood (Noah's 601st year)

sources.quote: And it came to pass **in the six hundredth and first year, in the first month, the first day of the month**, the waters were dried up from off the earth: and Noah **removed the covering of the ark**, and looked, and, behold, the face of the ground was dry.

events.title: Earth Completely Dry - Exit from Ark
events.description: In the 601st year, on the 27th day of the 2nd month, the earth was completely dried. God commands Noah, his family, and all the animals to exit the ark.

sources.quote: And in the **second month, on the seven and twentieth day of the month**, was the earth dried.
And God spake unto Noah, saying, **Go forth of the ark**, thou, and thy wife, and thy sons, and thy sons' wives with thee.

events.title: Rain Ends (40 Days Complete)
events.description: After 40 days and 40 nights of continuous rain, the rain from heaven is stopped. Waters continue to prevail on the earth for 150 days total.

sources.quote: And the rain was upon the earth **forty days and forty nights**.
The fountains also of the deep and the windows of heaven were stopped, and **the rain from heaven was restrained**.

events.title: Noah Builds Altar & Offers Sacrifice
events.description: After exiting the ark, Noah builds an altar unto the LORD and offers burnt offerings. God smells the sweet savor and promises never to curse the ground again or destroy all living things with a flood.

start.notes: Immediately after exiting the ark

sources.quote: And **Noah builded an altar** unto the LORD; and took of every clean beast, and of every clean fowl, and **offered burnt offerings** on the altar. And the LORD smelled a sweet savour.

events.title: Rainbow Covenant
events.description: God establishes His covenant with Noah and all living creatures - the rainbow is set as a sign that God will never again destroy the earth with a flood.

start.notes: Shortly after Noah's sacrifice

sources.quote: And God said, This is the **token of the covenant** which I make between me and you and every living creature that is with you, for perpetual generations: **I do set my bow in the cloud**, and it shall be for a token of a covenant between me and the earth.

events.title: Abraham Born
events.description: Abraham (Abram) is born to Terah. Calculated as 75 years before the Covenant (when Abraham was 75 years old).

sources.quote: And Terah lived seventy years, and begat Abram, Nahor, and Haran.

events.title: Abraham Departs from Haran
events.description: Abraham departs from Haran at age 75, entering Canaan and receiving the initial promise of land and descendants. This marks the beginning of God's covenant relationship with Abraham.

sources.quote: So Abram went, as the LORD had told him; and Lot went with him. **Abram was seventy-five years old** when he set out from Haran.

events.title: Abraham Separates from Lot
events.description: After entering Canaan, Abraham and Lot separate due to their herds being too large to dwell together. Abraham gives Lot the choice of land, and Lot chooses the well-watered plain of Jordan, settling near Sodom.

sources.quote: And Abram went up out of Egypt... And **the land was not able to bear them, that they might dwell together**... Then **Lot chose him all the plain of Jordan**.

events.title: Abraham Rescues Lot - War with Kings
events.description: Four kings (led by Chedorlaomer) defeat five kings of the plain (including the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah) and take Lot captive. Abraham, with 318 trained men, pursues and defeats the four kings, rescuing Lot and recovering all the goods.

sources.quote: And when Abram heard that his brother was taken captive, he armed his trained servants, born in his own house, three hundred and eighteen, and pursued them... And he brought back all the goods, and also brought again his brother Lot.
After this [the events of Gen 14], the word of the LORD came to Abram in a vision

events.title: Covenant with Abraham - Dark Night
events.description: On the 15th day of the 1st month, exactly 430 years to the day before the Exodus from Egypt, God makes a covenant with Abraham in a dark night. The emphasis on total darkness—'horror of great darkness' and 'it was dark'—suggests a dark moon, which aligns with the 15th being naturally dark if the month starts at full moon.

sources.quote: And when the sun was going down, a deep sleep fell upon Abram; and, lo, an horror of great darkness fell upon him.
And it came to pass, that, when the sun went down, and it was dark, behold a smoking furnace, and a burning lamp that passed between those pieces. In the same day the LORD made a covenant with Abram.

Now the sojourning of the children of Israel, who dwelt in Egypt, [was] four hundred and thirty years. And it came to pass at the end of the four hundred and thirty years, even the selfsame day it came to pass, that all the hosts of the LORD went out from the land of Egypt.
The covenant, that was confirmed before of God in Christ, the law, which was four hundred and thirty years after, cannot disannul.

events.title: Isaac Born
events.description: Isaac is born to Abraham (100 years old) and Sarah (90 years old), fulfilling God's promise of a son. This is 25 years after Abraham left Haran at age 75.

sources.quote: And **Abraham was an hundred years old**, when his son Isaac was born unto him.
Shall a child be born unto him that is **an hundred years old**? and shall Sarah, that is **ninety years old**, bear?

events.title: Isaac Marries Rebekah
events.description: Isaac marries Rebekah at age 40. Abraham's servant had been sent to find a wife for Isaac from Abraham's family in Mesopotamia.

sources.quote: And **Isaac was forty years old** when he took Rebekah to wife.

events.title: Jacob and Esau Born (Twins)
events.description: Twin sons Jacob and Esau are born to Isaac (60 years old) and Rebekah after 20 years of marriage. Esau was born first, with Jacob grasping his heel.

sources.quote: And after that came his brother out, and his hand took hold on Esau's heel; and his name was called Jacob: and **Isaac was threescore years old** when she bare them.

events.title: Abraham Dies
events.description: Abraham dies at age 175, 'in a good old age, an old man, and full of years.' Isaac and Ishmael bury him in the cave of Machpelah with Sarah.

sources.quote: And these are the days of the years of Abraham's life which he lived, **an hundred threescore and fifteen years**. Then Abraham gave up the ghost, and died in a good old age.

events.title: Jacob Flees to Laban
events.description: After deceiving Isaac to receive Esau's blessing, Jacob flees to his uncle Laban in Haran. Jacob was about 77 years old (derived: 130 when entering Egypt - 39 years Joseph's age - 14 years working for wives = 77).

sources.quote: And Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing... flee thou to Laban my brother to Haran.

events.notes: Age derived: Jacob was 130 when entering Egypt (Gen 47:9), Joseph was 39 at that time (30 + 7 + 2), Joseph born end of 14 years with Laban. So Jacob arrived at Laban at 130 - 39 - 14 = 77.

events.title: Jacob Marries Leah and Rachel
events.description: After working 7 years for Rachel, Jacob is deceived by Laban and given Leah instead. He then works another 7 years for Rachel, marrying her a week after Leah.

sources.quote: And Jacob served **seven years** for Rachel... Fulfil her week, and we will give thee this also for the service which thou shalt serve with me yet **seven other years**.

events.title: Joseph Born
events.description: Joseph is born to Jacob and Rachel at the end of Jacob's 14 years of service to Laban. Jacob was about 91 years old (77 + 14).

sources.quote: And God remembered Rachel... and she conceived, and bare a son... And it came to pass, when Rachel had born Joseph, that Jacob said unto Laban, Send me away.

events.notes: Joseph was born at end of 14 years service. Jacob entered Egypt at 130 when Joseph was 39, so Jacob was 91 when Joseph was born (130 - 39 = 91).

events.title: Jacob Returns to Canaan
events.description: After 20 years with Laban (14 for wives + 6 for flocks), Jacob returns to Canaan with his family, flocks, and possessions. On the way, he wrestles with God and is renamed Israel.

sources.quote: This **twenty years** have I been with thee... I served thee **fourteen years for thy two daughters**, and **six years for thy cattle**.
Thy name shall be called no more Jacob, but **Israel**: for as a prince hast thou power with God and with men.

events.title: Isaac Dies
events.description: Isaac dies at age 180. Jacob and Esau together bury their father.

sources.quote: And the days of Isaac were **an hundred and fourscore years**. And Isaac gave up the ghost, and died, and was gathered unto his people.

events.title: Joseph Sold into Slavery
events.description: Joseph's brothers sell him to Midianite merchants at age 17. He is taken to Egypt and sold to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh.

sources.quote: Joseph, being **seventeen years old**, was feeding the flock with his brethren.
Then there passed by Midianites merchantmen... and they brought Joseph into Egypt.

events.title: Joseph Before Pharaoh / 🌾 Years of Plenty Begin
events.description: At age 30, Joseph interprets Pharaoh's dreams and is made second in command over all Egypt. This begins the 7 years of plenty, during which Joseph gathers grain throughout Egypt.

sources.quote: And Joseph was **thirty years old** when he stood before Pharaoh king of Egypt.
Behold, there come **seven years of great plenty** throughout all the land of Egypt: And there shall arise after them **seven years of famine**.
And in the **seven plenteous years** the earth brought forth by handfuls. And he gathered up all the food of the seven years.

events.title: Seven Years of Famine Begin
events.description: The seven years of famine begin, as Joseph had prophesied. The famine was severe not only in Egypt but 'in all lands.' This famine would eventually bring Jacob's family to Egypt.

sources.quote: And the **seven years of dearth began to come**, according as Joseph had said: and the dearth was in all lands... And the **famine was over all the face of the earth**.

events.title: Seven Years of Famine End
events.description: The seven years of famine conclude. Egypt and the surrounding nations survived due to Joseph's wise administration during the years of plenty.

sources.quote: And there shall arise after them **seven years of famine**; and all the plenty shall be forgotten in the land of Egypt.

events.title: Jacob's Family Enters Egypt
events.description: Jacob (Israel) and his entire family move to Egypt in the **2nd year of famine**, settling in Goshen. Jacob was 130 years old; Joseph was 39 (30 + 7 years plenty + 2 years famine). Five years of famine remained.

sources.quote: For these **two years hath the famine been in the land**: and yet there are **five years**, in the which there shall neither be earing nor harvest.
And Jacob said unto Pharaoh, The days of the years of my pilgrimage are **an hundred and thirty years**.
And they took their cattle, and their goods... and came into Egypt, Jacob, and all his seed with him.

events.title: Jacob (Israel) Dies
events.description: Jacob dies in Egypt at age 147, after blessing his sons. His body is embalmed and carried back to Canaan for burial in the cave of Machpelah.

sources.quote: And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years: so the whole age of Jacob was **an hundred forty and seven years**.

events.title: Joseph Dies
events.description: Joseph dies in Egypt at age 110. Before dying, he makes the Israelites swear to carry his bones out of Egypt when God delivers them.

sources.quote: So Joseph died, being **an hundred and ten years old**: and they embalmed him, and he was put in a coffin in Egypt.
And Joseph took an oath of the children of Israel, saying, God will surely visit you, and ye shall carry up my bones from hence.

events.title: Thutmose III - Pharaoh of the Oppression
events.description: Thutmose III begins his sole reign over Egypt. He is the Pharaoh from whom Moses fled (Exodus 2:15), and who died after Moses had been in Midian for 40 years (Acts 7:30). events.title: Joshua's Long Day - Sun and Moon Stand Still

The biblical geometry precisely describes the locations: From Upper Beth Horon (observer: 31.87722°N, 35.11861°E), Gibeon (31.84750°N, 35.18639°E) was at ~118° azimuth (sun high in sky at dawn), while Aijalon (31.84028°N, 35.02250°E) was at ~296° azimuth (moon low on opposite horizon). The Book of Jasher (88:63-64) specifies this phenomenon lasted 36 moments (~36 minutes). More Amorites died from hailstones than from Israel's swords. The five kings hid in a cave at Makkedah—typological of the Day of the Lord when kings hide in caves (Revelation 6:15-17). The Gibeonites (Canaanites who made covenant with Israel) were spared—typological of nations seeking the LORD in the last days (Zechariah 8:20-23).

Day 15: The Ark is brought into the Most Holy Place and the glory of the LORD fills the Temple. Days 15-21: Seven days of the Feast of Tabernacles. Day 22: The solemn assembly (Shemini Atzeret). Day 23: Solomon blesses the people. After this celebration, the regular priestly rotations begin with Jehoiarib (Course 1).

events.title: 4th Year of Solomon's Reign
events.description: The 4th regal year of Solomon's reign (Fall 967 to Fall 966 BC). This is the year in which the Temple foundation was laid (1 Kings 6:1) and the 480th year after the Exodus. The regal year (Fall-to-Fall) spans two Spring-to-Spring calendar years: 967 BC and 966 BC. The temple foundation (Iyyar 2) falls in the Spring 966 BC portion.

start.notes: Derives from temple foundation (the anchor). Temple is Iyyar 2, 966 BC (Spring); 4th regal year starts the previous Spring-to-Spring year (Nisan 1, 967 BC).

sources.quote: in the fourth year of Solomon's reign over Israel, in the month Zif, which is the second month, that he began to build the house of the LORD.

events.title: Solomon's Temple Foundation Laid
events.description: On the 2nd day of the 2nd month (Iyyar 2) in the 4th year of Solomon's reign, construction of the First Temple begins. This is 480 years after the Exodus (1 Kings 6:1). This is the chronological ANCHOR — its date is fixed from Assyrian cross-checks and all other dates derive from it.

start.notes: ANCHOR: Iyyar 2, Spring 966 BC. Fixed date verified by Assyrian synchronisms. Solomon's 4th regal year (Fall 967 to Fall 966 BC).

events.title: Bur-Sagale Eclipse
events.description: Total solar eclipse recorded in Assyrian Eponym Lists during the eponymate of Bur-Sagale. This is the ROOT CHRONOLOGICAL ANCHOR for all Ancient Near Eastern chronology. Modern astronomical calculation confirms June 15, 763 BCE. The continuous Assyrian Eponym Lists count backward from this astronomically-verified date to establish absolute dates for Assyrian-Israelite synchronisms.

events.title: Battle of Qarqar
events.description: Major battle between Assyrian forces under Shalmaneser III and a coalition of Levantine states including 'Ahab the Israelite' who contributed 2,000 chariots and 10,000 soldiers. Recorded on the Kurkh Monolith, dated to Shalmaneser's 6th year, 90 eponym years before the Bur-Sagale eclipse. This is the first major Assyrian-Israelite synchronism.

Depicted on the Black Obelisk, dated to Shalmaneser's 18th year, 78 eponym years before the Bur-Sagale eclipse. The inscription calls him 'Jehu son of Omri'. This is the second major Assyrian-Israelite synchronism.

events.title: Shishak (Shoshenq I) Invades Judah
events.description: In the 5th year of Rehoboam, Pharaoh Shishak (Egyptian: Shoshenq I) invades Judah with 1,200 chariots, 60,000 horsemen, and innumerable troops. He takes the fortified cities and comes to Jerusalem, carrying away the treasures of the Temple and the king's house. This is the CRITICAL EGYPTIAN SYNCHRONISM: Shoshenq I's campaign is recorded on the Bubastite Portal at Karnak, listing over 150 conquered cities. Egyptian chronology dates Shoshenq I's campaign to ~925 BC, which aligns with Rehoboam's 5th year (~926-925 BC) calculated from Assyrian synchronisms—providing independent verification of biblical chronology.

start.notes: ~925 BC - Rehoboam's 5th year. Egyptian chronology independently dates Shoshenq I's campaign to this period.

This pharaoh provides the critical link between Egyptian and biblical chronology for the Divided Kingdom period.

events.title: Ezekiel's Prophecy Against Tyre (Babylon the Great)
events.description: In the 12th year of King Jehoiachin's exile—the year after the First Temple fell—Ezekiel receives a prophecy against Tyre. Because Tyre gloated over Jerusalem's fall ('The gate to the nations is broken... I will be filled'), God declares judgment: **many nations will rise like waves**, Tyre will become **a bare rock for spreading nets**, and will **never be rebuilt**. While historically Nebuchadnezzar and Alexander partially fulfilled this, the 'never rebuilt' clause (v. 14, 21) suggests a dual/typological layer pointing to **Babylon the Great** (Revelation 17-18). Revelation 18 directly echoes Ezekiel 26-27: merchants/kings weeping, sudden ruin, 'found no more forever.' Ezekiel 28's description of Tyre's king as a fallen cherub in Eden links to satanic influence behind the final Antichrist system.

sources.quote: In the eleventh month of the twelfth year, on the first day of the month, the word of the LORD came to me... **I am against you, O Tyre, and I will raise up many nations against you, as the sea brings up its waves**
I will make thee like the top of a rock: thou shalt be a place to spread nets upon; **thou shalt be built no more**: for I the LORD have spoken it
I will make thee a terror, and **thou shalt be no more**: though thou be sought for, yet shalt thou **never be found again**, saith the Lord GOD
Thus with violence shall that great city Babylon be thrown down, and shall be **found no more at all**

details.heading: "Never be rebuilt" as permanent, end-times desolation
details.text: Ezekiel 26:14 says Tyre 'shall never be rebuilt' and 'be no more forever' (cf. v. 21), yet modern Tyre exists as a city. This suggests the prophecy has a dual/typological layer: partial historical fulfillment (Nebuchadnezzar, Alexander), but ultimate total/irreversible ruin in the future—like Babylon the Great's final fall ('found no more forever,' Rev 18:21).

details.heading: Symbolic 'bare rock' and fishing nets
details.text: The site becomes a bare rock for nets (Ezek 26:4-5,14), symbolizing utter stripping of glory/power. Babylon the Great ends similarly—utterly desolate, mourned by merchants, never restored (Rev 18:17-19,21).

details.heading: Commercial pride and global trade parallels
details.text: Tyre's wealth from worldwide merchants (Ezek 27) mirrors Babylon the Great's luxury trade list (Rev 18:11-13). Both are proud empires judged for exploiting nations/God's people.

details.heading: Gloating over Jerusalem's fall
details.text: Tyre rejoices at Jerusalem's ruin for gain (Ezek 26:2), typifying Babylon the Great's spiritual/economic opposition to saints (Rev 17:6; 18:24).

details.heading: Multi-nation waves of judgment
details.text: 'Many nations' attack like sea waves (Ezek 26:3); Babylon the Great falls when kings/beast turn on her (Rev 17:16-17), fulfilling the 'many nations' in an end-times context.

details.heading: Satanic ruler behind the city
details.text: Ezekiel 28 (tied to Tyre oracle) describes the king as a fallen cherub in Eden (v. 12-19), linking to satanic influence. Babylon the Great rides the beast (Satanic power, Rev 17:3-7), making Tyre a type of the final Antichrist system.

details.heading: Revelation's heavy borrowing from Ezekiel's Tyre oracles
details.text: Rev 18 directly echoes Ezekiel 26–27 (merchants/kings weeping, sudden ruin, dust on heads, 'Who is like the great city?'). This intertextual link shows John applying Tyre's judgment as a foreshadowing of Babylon the Great's eschatological destruction.

details.heading: Prophecy's dual near/far application
details.text: Biblical pattern (e.g., Antichrist types in history) allows partial fulfillment historically while reserving full 'never rebuilt' permanence for the end-times entity—ancient Tyre partially judged but 'rebuilt' modestly; Babylon the Great never recovers.

events.description: During Belshazzar's feast, a hand appears and writes on the wall: MENE, MENE, TEKEL, UPHARSIN. Daniel interprets: 'Thy kingdom is divided, and given to the Medes and Persians.' That very night Belshazzar is slain and Darius the Mede takes the kingdom. The Nabonidus Chronicle records that Babylon fell on the 16th of Tishri—during the Feast of Tabernacles!

events.title: Fall of the Second Temple (Tisha B'Av)
events.description: The Second Temple is destroyed by the Romans under Titus. Jewish tradition commemorates this as Tisha B'Av (9th of Av), though Josephus indicates the burning began on the 10th of Av—exactly 657 years after the First Temple's destruction on the same date. This is 107 years from 'the days of Herod' when he began appointing high priests. Josephus confirms Jehoiarib (Course 1) was serving—the same course as at the First Temple's fall—providing a critical anchor for reconstructing the priestly cycle.

events.title: First Year of Jesus' Ministry
events.description: The period between the first and second Passovers of Jesus' public ministry (30-31 AD). This year includes: the first Temple cleansing and dialogue about '46 years' of construction (John 2:13-22); Nicodemus visiting Jesus by night (John 3:1-21); Jesus and His disciples baptizing in Judea while John baptizes at Aenon (John 3:22-36); the journey through Samaria and the woman at the well (John 4:1-42); healing the nobleman's son at Capernaum (John 4:46-54); an unnamed feast in Jerusalem, likely Pentecost or Tabernacles (John 5:1); the healing at the Pool of Bethesda and the ensuing conflict over healing on the Sabbath (John 5:2-18); and Jesus' discourse on His authority from the Father (John 5:19-47). During this year, Jesus also began His Galilean ministry, calling His first disciples and performing many signs.

events.detailsTitle: The 'Woman' in the Basket — Fire Offering?

details.heading: Hebrew Word Ambiguity: Woman or Fire?
details.text: In Hebrew, 'woman' (אִשָּׁה, ishah) and 'fire offering' (אִשֶּׁה, isheh) are spelled identically without vowel points—vowels were added later by tradition. The consonantal text allows for an alternate reading: not a 'woman' but a 'fire/fire offering' in the basket.

details.heading: The Ephah's Dimensions
details.text: The ephah (measuring basket) described has specific dimensions—a cylindrical container. With a talent of lead (approximately 70 pounds) as its covering/payload, the proportions remarkably match modern submarine-launched ballistic missiles.

details.heading: Flying Cylinder Carried by Wings
details.text: Two figures with wings 'like the wings of a stork' lift the ephah between heaven and earth, carrying it to the land of Shinar (Babylon). This describes a flying cylindrical object with a heavy lead payload being delivered to bring destruction.

details.heading: Connection to Babylon's Destruction
details.text: The destination is Shinar/Babylon, where a 'house' is built for it. Combined with Revelation's description of Babylon the Great's sudden destruction 'in one hour' by fire (Rev 18:8-10, 17-19), this vision may prophetically describe the weapon of that judgment—a fire that consumes everything.
